I.   INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  Review  Mission  for  the  gender  strategy  and 
implementation plan for agriculture and rural development1 in February 2004, the Ministry of 
Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  (MARD)  explored  the  possibility  of  ADB  providing 
assistance to support follow-up activities.  A brief proposal was sent to ADB in March 2004 and 
discussed during the Country Programming Mission in April 2004. The TA Fact-Finding Mission2 
visited Viet Nam from 19 to 30 July and 16 to 18 September 2004, and held discussions with the 
Government of Viet Nam on the goal, purpose, scope, implementation arrangements, cost, 
financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services.  The Government 
confirmed the mission’s Aide Mémoire on 7 October 2004. The Gender and Development 
Cooperation Fund donors gave concept clearance for financing the TA3 in July 2004. The TA 
Framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES4 
2.  During the economic reform process, farming households in Viet Nam acquired more 
rights and more important roles as self-administered units. Households received rights to long-
term use of land, and the power to make decisions on labor division, production, trade, and 
investment. However, reform policies have often targeted men as heads of households. The fact 
that women have benefited less than men from the reform process not only influences the 
household economy, but also creates an overall development constraint in the agriculture and 
rural development sector as women constitute more than half of the agricultural labor force.5 
Greater efforts are required to develop the potential of rural women, help them to quickly gain 
the capacity and confidence to play a key role in the sector, and empower them to be effective 
and equal partners of men. 
 
3.  A number of challenges need to be met before such empowerment and equality are 
realized. First, social behaviors and attitudes to women remain patriarchal. Rural families tend 
to be largely controlled by men, and women defer to them throughout their lives. Within the 
MARD bureaucracy and among officials and public service providers in the field, social attitudes 
to gender roles, gender equality, division of labor, and leadership, and decision making continue 
to be biased by traditional values and gender stereotypes. Gender awareness and sensitivity 
are generally low in the sector.  
 
4.  Second, although the lives of most people living in rural areas have improved, men still 
have greater access than women to and control of resources critical to rural livelihoods. For 
example, while women represent half to three quarters of the workforce in animal husbandry, 
depending on the region, only about 20% of extension training courses on animal husbandry are 
attended by women. Despite the fact that 80% of rural women work in cultivation, they represent

account for about 28% of the total, but generally their capacity to provide services remains low. 
It is difficult to recruit qualified women extension workers, especially at the commune level. 
Women are less able than men to take advantage of agricultural extension services and inputs. 
 
5.  Third,  MARD’s  institutional  capacity  to  mainstream  gender  within  its  functional 
responsibilities and internal operations is limited by a lack of human and financial resources, 
institutional  procedures  and  norms  and  organizational  culture,  among  other  factors.  The 
capacity to make operations within MARD’s functional and management departments more 
gender-responsive is limited to a few members of the Committee for the Advancement of 
Women  (CFAW).  MARD  has  no  gender-sensitive  planning  and  monitoring  and  evaluation 
system.  Planning  processes  and  administrative  reforms  do  not  systematically  take  gender 
issues into account. Women’s participation in decision making is low throughout the sector.  
 
6.   In response to these challenges, with support from a previous TA (footnote 1), MARD 
developed a gender strategy in agriculture and rural development to 2010 (the gender strategy) 
and a gender plan of action in agriculture and rural development to the year 2005 (the plan of 
action).6 The previous TA used a highly participatory approach designed to increase MARD’s 
internal capacity for mainstreaming gender in its operations. Consultations with stakeholders 
allowed MARD staff to observe and learn about gender-based constraints and needs directly. 
MARD has shown commitment to implementing gender mainstreaming: at the end of 2003 it 
included some of the targets identified in the gender strategy in its planning and policy; and 
some gender perspectives have been included in the curriculum of the Agriculture and Rural 
Development Management School I under MARD. The major challenge ahead is how to realize 
the  thrusts  of  the  gender  strategy  by  taking  the  actions  stipulated  in  the  plan  of  action 
systematically, taking into account the entire institutional context.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
7.  The purpose of the TA is to support the Government to achieve the overall objective of 
the plan of action: to integrate gender into MARD’s plans, programs, and projects in order to 
achieve gender equality and consequent socioeconomic benefits. More specifically, the TA will 
assist MARD to implement the actions identified under two of the three objectives of the plan of 
action: (i) increase MARD’s commitment to implementing gender equality in developing and 
improving its agricultural and rural development institutions (objective 1), and (ii) strengthen the 
capacity of gender mainstreaming for officials and public service providers at all levels of 
MARD-related departments and agencies (objective 2).  
 
8.   The TA outputs will be (i) MARD’s annual plans with gender-disaggregated targets; (ii) 
the integration of gender into MARD’s public service provision (contents and delivery); (iii) a 
training  framework,  modules,  and  curriculum  for  gender  mainstreaming  geared  to  public 
servants, teachers in MARD-related schools, and service providers; (iv) gender training geared 
to different roles and responsibilities of offices and units; and (v) a network of human resources 
for gender integration for the programs and projects of MARD across the board.  The TA will 
strengthen MARD’s gender mainstreaming capacity at the organizational level as a whole, as 
well as at the departmental level.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.   Among  the  three  constraints  on  realizing  gender  equality  and  empowerment  in 
agriculture and rural development discussed above, the TA will focus on institutional constraints. 
The TA generally follows the steps identified in the plan of action, and will coordinate closely 
with the ongoing Agriculture Sector Development Program7 and Agriculture Sector Development 
Support8  which  address  the  constraints  relating  to  recurrent  budget  allocations  to  support 
services and their implications for the implementation of the gender action plan. The TA will also 
coordinate closely with the Project Support to the Public Administration Reform Program in 
MARD9 with regard to gender mainstreaming. The TA has four components. 
 
1.  Strengthening Gender-integrated Planning Cycle 
10.  This component aims to support MARD’s commitment to implementing gender equality 
in developing and improving its institutions concerned with agricultural and rural development. In 
accordance with the decree defining the functions and organizational structure of MARD issued 
by the Government in July 2003, and subsequent ministerial decisions defining the functions 
and organizational structure of each of the 18 departments issued in September 2003, the 
organizational structure and procedures and the systems for gender integration in the planning 
cycle will be examined. Emphasis will be placed on clarity of responsibilities and tasks of 
different departments and units with regard to gender mainstreaming and developing gender-
integrated planning at each stage of MARD’s planning cycle. Gender issues relating to daily 
work at department, division, and individual levels will be examined in light of job descriptions 
and  performance  indicators,  which  will  eventually  be  integrated  into  the  planning  cycle.  A 
handbook on gender mainstreaming in the planning cycle will be issued. 
 
11.  Effective planning will require accurate and updated information on gender relations and 
gender  disparities.  To  date,  some  gender-disaggregated  data  in  agriculture  and  rural 
development have been collected and used on a project-by-project basis, but there is no means 
of collecting, storing, analyzing, and monitoring gender-disaggregated data systematically. The 
TA will support the preparation of a detailed plan to establish a gender-disaggregated database 
with a set of indicators at the Planning and Projections Department. Guidelines on planning and 
monitoring with gender-disaggregated data will be issued for use by staff.  Pilot projects to 
collect data may be carried out in selected provinces.  
 
2.  Capacity Building for Gender Mainstreaming  
12.  This component will strengthen institutional and staff capacity to mainstream gender in 
key departments’ scope of work, based on their functions and organizational responsibilities. 
Gender  training  will  cover  technical  and  professional  subjects  (e.g.,  the  role  of  gender  in 
livestock,  forestry,  irrigation,  and  water  management);  gender  analysis  and  planning;  and 
gender issues in management and leadership.  As a number of gender training materials have 
already been developed at MARD, these will be compiled and consolidated to form the basis of 
standardized modules, which can be modified to serve specific training needs, in accordance 
with the mandate, functions, and organizational structure of each department.  The training and

the training modules will be based on basic gender concepts and sensitivity and will cater to the 
needs of MARD leaders (deputy directors and above). Technical and professional training will 
focus on the staff. Activities will include training needs assessment, development of training 
frameworks and modules, pilot-testing of modules, and training of trainers.   
 
13.  The TA will strengthen the institutional capacity of Agriculture and Rural Development 
Management Schools I and II under MARD, which train civil servants, specialists, and managers 
of cooperatives and agricultural enterprises. Some of the training courses are unsystematic, 
scattered, and not standardized. The TA will help revise training content, methods, and the 
curriculum to cater to the emerging needs and demands of MARD departments, and to improve 
lecturers’ training methods.  The skills of the lecturers will be strengthened so they can make full 
use of the new curriculum and teaching methods.  
 
14.  To promote sustainable rural development and effective delivery of services to rural 
households, the TA will support the establishment of gender-sensitive extension services and 
alternative means of service delivery. Under this subcomponent, extension service materials will 
be  reviewed  and  extension  modules  for  gender  integration  developed,  using  innovative 
approaches. The National Agriculture Extension Center will organize training of trainers for 
extension  service  providers  in  selected  provinces. The TA  will  coordinate  closely  with  the 
Agriculture  Sector  Development  Program  in  assessing the  effectiveness  of  overall  support 
service  delivery,  including  budget  and  human  resource  constraints  across  MARD  and 
Department  of  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development,  particularly  those  affecting  women 
agricultural extension workers. 
 
3.  Gender Mainstreaming in ADB Projects 
15.  This component will facilitate and ensure gender mainstreaming in a number of ADB-
assisted projects10 and pilot-test the gender training and agricultural extension service modules 
developed under component 2. The staff trained under the capacity-building component will 
identify  project-specific  gender  issues  in  consultation  with  project  staff.  They  will  develop 
gender-mainstreaming objectives and targets under the projects and monitor activities. Periodic 
meetings will be held to review progress. Emphasis will be placed on gender capacity building at 
district and commune levels in the project areas, including the training of agricultural extension 
workers. Alternative ways of delivering extension services will be explored. Through these 
exercises, a critical mass of people with gender analysis and planning skills will be developed 
within MARD, through “learning by doing.”   
 
4.  Evaluation of Plan of Action  
16.  The plan of action covers the actions to be taken up to 2005.  It will be timely for the TA 
to evaluate the effectiveness of the plan of action, as the TA will be completed several months 
after the plan of action period.  The TA will develop a framework for assessment and analyze 
how objectives are met and outputs produced, and if not, why not. The evaluation will also take 
into account assistance and support to MARD, particularly the Project Support to the Public

department personnel and ADB project counterparts. 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $315,000 equivalent, of which $123,000 is the 
foreign exchange cost and $192,000 equivalent is the local currency cost.  The Government has 
requested ADB to finance $250,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and 
$127,000 equivalent of the local currency cost.  The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the  
Gender and Development Cooperation Fund, to be administered by ADB.  The Government will 
finance the  balance  of  the  local  currency  cost,  equivalent  to  $65,000  in  kind  through the 
provision of counterpart and support staff, office accommodation, and other related services and 
facilities. Cost estimates and the financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  MARD will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The chairperson of CFAW-MARD will be 
the TA director and will be responsible for day-to-day TA implementation. A TA coordination 
committee with representatives from key departments and offices of MARD will be formed to 
monitor and provide technical support to the TA activities. The coordination committee will be 
chaired  by  the  vice  chairperson,  CFAW-MARD.  The  coordination  committee  members  will 
ensure  effective  coordination  between  the  TA  and  the  departments  or  offices  concerned. 
Information on members and draft outline terms of reference for the coordination committee are 
in  Appendix  3.    The  composition,  terms  of  reference,  and  detailed  work  program  of  the 
coordination committee will be discussed and finalized at the beginning of the TA.  
 
19.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months, from May 2005 to April 2006, and will 
require 26 person-months of consulting services: 6 person-months of international consulting 
services  and  20  person-months  of  domestic  consulting  services.  The  consultants  will  be 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its Guidelines  on  the  Use  of Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for the engagement of domestic consultants. The consultants 
will  be  recruited  as  individuals.  Appendix  4  gives  the  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the 
consultants. The consultants  will  submit  inception,  interim,  and final reports,  and quarterly 
progress reports to ADB. Equipment for the TA will be financed by ADB in accordance with ADB  
Guidelines for Procurement. 
 
 20.  A participatory approach is an integral part of the TA. The coordination committee will 
ensure that the work program and activities will be developed through a consultative process. 
The TA outputs will be disseminated through the coordination committee to the entire MARD.  
TA inception, review, and final meetings will be organized with stakeholders. The outcomes and 
lessons learned will be posted on the ADB gender and development Web site. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to the Government 
of Viet Nam to be financed on a grant basis by the Gender and Development Cooperation Fund 
for the Gender Mainstreaming Action Plan for Agriculture and Rural Development, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Roles and Responsibilities 
 
1.  The coordination committee shall be responsible for monitoring the implementation of all 
technical assistance (TA) activities in accordance with the approved work plan and budget. 
 
2.  The coordination committee shall meet bimonthly to review the status of the TA, including 
the progress of the work plans and utilization of the budgets and ensure compliance with all 
government reporting and financial regulations. 
 
3.  The  coordination  committee  shall  ensure  coordination  among  the  team  leader,  TA 
consultants, MARD TA counterparts, Agriculture Sector Development Program, Agriculture 
Sector Development Support, Project Support to the Public Administration Reform Program 
in MARD, and the gender task force of the Project Support to the Public Administration 
Reform Program in MARD. 
 
4.  The  coordination  committee  shall  ensure  that  information  on  the  status  of  the 
implementation will be exchanged periodically at the joint meeting with the gender task force 
of the PAR Project. 
 
5.  The coordination committee members will participate in inception, midterm, and final reviews 
of the TA and provide recommendations for follow-up.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Team Leader and Institution and Human Resource Development Specialist 
(international, 4 person-months) 
1.  The team leader will be responsible for coordination with the TA coordination committee,  
Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) Committee for the Advancement of 
Women, and gender task force of the Project Support to the Public Administration Reform 
Program in MARD with regard to gender aspects. The team leader will  
 
(i)  support MARD in mainstreaming gender in the agriculture and rural development 
sector and provide overall planning, coordination, and management of the TA; 
(ii)  develop a detailed work plan for the TA containing the information on the planned 
activities, timing, budgets, and consultants’ inputs; 
(iii)  guide the activities of the consultants and provide administrative management 
and accounting; 
(iv)  review the mandate, organizational structure, and tasks of  MARD departments, 
in  particular,  Department  of  Organization  and  Personnel,  Planning  and 
Projections  Department,  Agriculture  and  Rural  Development  Management 
School  1,  Cooperatives  and  Rural  Development  Department,  Department  of 
Agriculture, Department of Animal Health, Department of Irrigation and Water 
Management, and National Center for Agricultural Extension, and assess their 
institutional capacity to integrate gender perspectives into their operations; 
(v)  review  job  descriptions  of  MARD  staff  and  assess  their  effectiveness  to 
implement the actions needed to mainstream gender; 
(vi)  based  on  the  above  assessment  and  consultations  with  the  MARD  staff 
concerned, examine how to incorporate gender perspectives fully into each stage 
of MARD’s planning cycle and day-to-day operations; 
(vii)  help  MARD  introduce  gender-sensitive  planning,  monitoring,  budgeting,  and 
evaluation and prepare a handbook; 
(viii)  review available gender training materials within MARD and other agencies (e.g., 
the Viet Nam Women’s Union) and develop training modules by compiling and 
consolidating materials to meet the specific needs of departments and offices in 
accordance with their mandate and functions;
